childMarkdownRemark.html: You can develop your professional or management skills by undertaking an apprenticeship relevant to your role. These are nationally recognised work-based programmes and lead to accredited professional qualifications. They’re ideal if you’re wanting to increase your skills as part of your career development.

collapsibleLinks.title: What does an apprenticeship programme include
collapsibleLinks.ariaLabel: What does an apprenticeship programme include

childMarkdownRemark.html:
• Workshops - monthly interactive workshops with a group of peers. All workshops are led by qualified tutors with a wealth of experience.
  • Resources - students have access to high quality online resources and reference materials and will create a learning log.
  • Personal tutor – a dedicated tutor from the apprenticeship training provider who will be there to support you. Bringing their expertise they will guide throughout the programme.
  • Line manager - support is vital to success, working together to develop skills will benefit the whole team.
  • Peer support - creates a supportive environment to learn. Studying in groups builds strong bonds and builds networks.
  • Assessment – there are milestones throughout the programme with an end point assessment to establish grades achieved.
  • Off-the-job learning – 20% of working time must be dedicated to learning. This can be made up of training sessions, shadowing, mentor assessments, gaining practical application of the learning, work experience placements, assignments, and possibly secondments for higher level apprenticeships

1. First step is to talk to your line manager and discuss how an apprenticeship could help you develop your career. Your line manager will need to agree the request with your Service Director.
  2. Search the available apprenticeship programmes to see what is suitable to your role and career aspirations on the Bucks Adult Learning and the Institute of Apprenticeships websites. Contact the apprenticeships co-ordinator if you cannot find what you’re looking for.
  3. When you have found the apprenticeship programme that is right for you, and it has been agreed with your manager and Service Director, complete the Upskilling Apprenticeship Nomination Form and email to apprenticeships@buckinghamshire.gov.uk.

• Upskilling apprenticeships are open to all job grades, but you will need the scope within your role to cover the skills and knowledge requirements of your chosen apprenticeship and be able to evidence that you will gain ‘significant new skills’ by undertaking the apprenticeship
  • An apprenticeship programme is a big commitment and will require you to be able to work on your own between tutor and training sessions as well as balance your work demands alongside studying
  • You must spend at least 20% of your contracted hours in off-the-job-learning, and you and your manager will need to evidence this throughout the programme.
  • You and your line manager will sign an Employer Apprenticeship Agreement which sets out the expectations of you as you undertake the apprenticeship, and their commitment to support you
  • Apprenticeships take between 18 months and 4 years depending on the level and discipline
  • Your salary stays the same whilst you undertake an apprenticeship and there are no changes to your terms and conditions of employment. Training costs are paid for by Apprenticeship Levy Funds.
  • You will need to be on a permanent contract to be eligible

collapsibleLinks.title: I’m managing an apprentice, what do I need to know
collapsibleLinks.ariaLabel: I’m managing an apprentice, what do I need to know

childMarkdownRemark.html:
• Make time to regularly join in with the tutor-apprentice meetings. Even if it’s just for the first 10 minutes of the session, it’s your chance to keep up to date with their progress and show your support. It will also help you plan any new areas of work you could be giving them and support your C4P discussions. At the very least, you MUST attend any quarterly 3-way reviews between the training provider, you and your team member.
  • Help your staff member to manage their time effectively and, if needs be, delegate tasks to other team members to allow them to take the 20% off-the-job-learning time.
  • Support your member of staff to fulfil the 20% off-the-job-learning requirement. Remember that this is to spend 20% of their working hours (over the duration of the programme) learning new skills/completing assignments/work shadowing/attending actual training sessions. The tutor can help you determine what counts towards the 20%.
  • Flag up any concerns you have about progress with the tutor. They are there to advise you as an employer and will want to work with you so that your staff member successfully completes their qualification.
  • Feedback to apprenticeships@buckinghamshire.gov.uk if you have any concerns about the training provider’s delivery of the apprenticeship, which you cannot resolve with them yourself.

Whether you’re new to a management role (people or project) or looking to take the next step to a more senior, strategic position, we have an apprenticeship programme that could help you develop the skills, confidence and experience to help you thrive.
